abstract: Jamie Dimon, the outspoken boss of JPMorgan Chase, was one of the few major bank heads to fail to receive an invitation to the signing of the U.S. financial reform bill Wednesday, Reuters reported.
snippet: Jamie Dimon, the outspoken boss of JPMorgan Chase, was one of the few major bank heads to fail to receive an invitation to the signing of the U.S. financial reform bill Wednesday, Reuters reported.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, JPMorgan Chase‘s  chief executive,  Jamie Dimon, will be left out in the cold.

headline.main: JPMorgan’s Dimon Not Invited to U.S. Bill Signing

abstract: Morgan Stanley’s core trading unit surprised investors on Wednesday by reporting a relatively small 15 percent drop-off in revenue in the second quarter from the first quarter.
snippet: Morgan Stanley’s core trading unit surprised investors on Wednesday by reporting a relatively small 15 percent drop-off in revenue in the second quarter from the first quarter.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley’s core trading unit surprised investors on Wednesday by reporting a relatively small 15 percent drop-off in revenue in the second quarter from the first quarter. In contrast, its main competitors, Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, experienced 35 percent declines in trading revenue in the same period.

headline.main: How Morgan Stanley Bucked a Trend in Trading

abstract: Morgan Stanley, buoyed by rising revenue, set aside 37 percent more money to pay employees in the first half of this year.
snippet: Morgan Stanley, buoyed by rising revenue, set aside 37 percent more money to pay employees in the first half of this year.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley, buoyed by rising revenue, set aside 37 percent more money to pay employees in the first half of this year, even as Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase’s investment bank lowered their compensation expenses, Bloomberg News reports.

headline.main: Morgan Stanley Sets Aside More Money for Pay
